summary_visit.AdmissionSummary: A 35-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus was admitted on 09/07/2024 with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) following a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain, vomiting, altered mental status, and poor insulin adherence due to illness. On admission, he was tachycardic, dehydrated, and lethargic, with laboratory findings confirming severe hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis. Initial management included aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, insulin drip initiation, electrolyte correction, and continuous monitoring. Endocrinology and gastroenterology consultations were obtained to address his DKA and ongoing H. pylori treatment.

medications.name: Normal Saline
medications.dosage: 1,000 mL bolus followed by 60 mL/hour infusion

notes.note_content:
Date: 09/07/2024 

Author: Andrew Smith, MD

Subjective: 

  • CC: Altered mental status, abdominal pain, vomiting, and shortness of breath. 
  • HPI: A 35-year-old male with a known history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered mental status. He reports poor oral intake and decreased insulin dosing due to illness. 

Objective:

  • Vitals: T: 101.2 F, HR: 120 bpm, RR 24, BP 100/60 mmHg, O2 Sat 92% on RA, 70kg 
  • Physical Exam:  
    • General: Appears ill, lethargic, and dehydrated. 
    • Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. 
    • Respiratory: Tachypneic, clear lung fields. 
    • Abdomen: Tender to palpation, hypoactive bowel sounds. 
    • Neurological: Somnolent, sluggish pupillary response. 
  • Labs:  
    • CBC: WBC 15,000/µL, Hgb 12 g/dL, Hct 36% o
    • BMP: Na 132 mEq/L, K 3.5 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L, CO2 15 mmol/L, BUN 20 mg/dL, Cr 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose 450 mg/dL 
    • ABG: pH 7.25, PaCO2 30 mmHg, PaO2 90 mmHg, HCO3 12 mmol/L 
    • Urinalysis: Ketones ++, glucose +++
  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: Clear lungs 

Assessment: 

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • Dehydration
  • Acute gastroenteritis
  • H Pylori infection (treatment day 10) 

Plan:

  • Admit to the medical ICU 
  • Aggressive fluid resuscitation with normal saline 
  • Insulin drip initiation 
  • Electrolyte replacement 
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring 
  • Consult endocrinology

Date: 09/07/2024 

Pharmacist: Whitney Trelelis, PharmD

Patient Name: Donny Dunlap 

Medical Record Number: 361412

Home Medications:

  • Insulin: lispro 15u per carbohydrate exchange 40:1 correction ratio, glargine 15 units daily at bedtime - Continued as per endocrinology consult
  • H. pylori Treatment:  
    • Omeprazole: 40mg twice daily - Day 10 of 14-day course 
    • Clarithromycin: 500mg twice daily - Day 10 of 14-day course 
    • Amoxicillin: 500mg twice daily - Day 10 of 14-day course 

Hospital Medications:

  • Insulin: 6u/h - IV insulin drip 
  • Normal Saline: 60mL/h - IV fluid 
  • Potassium Chloride: 20mEq/L- IV supplement 

Recommendations: 

  • Continue home medications as prescribed upon discharge. 
  • Schedule a follow-up H. pylori test in 4 weeks. 
  • Monitor blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin dosing as needed. 
  • Advise patient to contact their primary care physician or endocrinologist for any concerns or questions.

Date: 09/08/2024

Author: Sarah Burlington, MD

Subjective:

  • Patient remains lethargic but is arousable to voice.
  • Reports persistent nausea and abdominal pain.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 99.8°F, HR 100 bpm, RR 20, BP 110/70 mmHg, O2 Sat 95% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Less lethargic, improved skin turgor.
    • Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm.
    • Respiratory: Tachypneic, clear lung fields.
    • Abdomen: Soft, tenderness improving.
    • Neurological: Arousable, oriented to person, place, and time.
  • Labs:
    • BMP: Na 135 mEq/L, K 4.0 mEq/L, Cl 105 mEq/L, CO2 20 mmol/L, BUN 18 mg/dL, Cr 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose 150 mg/dL
    • ABG: pH 7.35, PaCO2 35 mmHg, PaO2 92 mmHg, HCO3 20 mmol/L

Assessment:

  • Improving DKA
  • Mild dehydration

Plan:

  • Continue insulin drip and electrolyte replacement
  • Advance diet as tolerated
  • Monitor for hypoglycemia

Date: 09/09/2024

Author: Victoria Reynalds, MD

Subjective:

  • Patient reports feeling less nauseous and abdominal pain has improved.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.6°F, HR 90 bpm, RR 18, BP 115/75 mmHg, O2 Sat 96% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Improved mental status, alert and oriented.
    • Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
    • Respiratory: Clear lung fields.
    • Abdomen: Soft, mild tenderness.
    • Neurological: Normal neurological exam.
  • Labs:
    • BMP: Na 136 mEq/L, K 4.2 mEq/L, Cl 104 mEq/L, CO2 22 mmol/L, BUN 16 mg/dL, Cr 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose 120 mg/dL
    • ABG: pH 7.40, PaCO2 40 mmHg, PaO2 95 mmHg, HCO3 24 mmol/L

Assessment:

  • Significant improvement in DKA
  • Resolving gastroenteritis

Plan:

  • Continue insulin drip and taper as needed
  • Advance diet as tolerated
  • Consult gastroenterology for H. pylori treatment

Date: 09/11/2024

Author: Victoria Reynalds, MD

Subjective:

  • Patient reports feeling much better. No nausea or vomiting.
  • Abdominal pain has resolved.

Objective:

  • Vitals: T 98.2°F, HR 85 bpm, RR 16, BP 120/80 mmHg, O2 Sat 98% on RA
  • Physical Exam:
    • General: Appears well, alert, and oriented.
    • Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs.
    • Respiratory: Clear lung fields.
    • Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.
    • Neurological: Normal neurological exam.
  • Labs:
    • BMP: Normal electrolytes
    • HgbA1c: 8.5%

Assessment:

  • Resolved DKA
  • Improved glycemic control
  • Discontinued H. pylori treatment

Plan:

  • Discontinue insulin drip and transition to subcutaneous insulin
  • Continue H. pylori treatment
  • Advance diet as tolerated
  • Plan for discharge

Date: 09/12/2024

Author: Victoria Reynalds, MD

Subjective:

  • Patient reports feeling well. Tolerating diet well.

Objective:

  • Vitals: Stable vital signs
  • Physical Exam: Unremarkable physical exam
  • Labs:
    • BMP: Normal electrolytes
    • HgbA1c: Stable

Assessment:

  • Stable clinical condition
  • Tolerating oral intake

Plan:

  • Continue current medical management
  • Anticipate discharge in the next 24-48 hours

Date: 09/13/2024

Author: Andrew Smith, MD

Subjective:

  • Patient reports feeling well. Tolerating diet well.

Objective:

  • Vitals: Stable vital signs
  • Physical Exam: Unremarkable physical exam
  • Labs:
    • BMP: Normal electrolytes
    • HgbA1c: Stable

Assessment:

  • Stable clinical condition
  • Tolerating oral intake
  • Completed H. pylori treatment

Plan:

  • Discharge patient home on outpatient follow-up with endocrinology and primary care
  • Continue insulin therapy and diabetes education
  • Follow-up H. pylori test in 4 weeks

medication_orders.name: Omeprazole
recommendation_notes: Patient showing decreased symptoms of GERD.
No significant acid reflux observed over the last 3 months.
